Generate Ohlberger Figure 2: \(S_{MSY}\) at first post-historical review

Source: R/make_Ohlberger_figure_2.R
dot-make_Ohlberger_figure_2.Rd

Reproduces the published Figure 2. For each scenario, we extract the \(S_{MSY}\) value at the first review at or after the end of the historical period (\(nyi + nyh\)), then summarize across iterations within each (trends × selectivity × mgmt) cell. The plot shows medians (points) with central 50% and 80% intervals (vertical bars). Columns = gear selectivity; x = demographic trend scenarios; color = management method (TRM/YPR/DLM).

Usage

.make_Ohlberger_figure_2(
  data,
  output_dir = tempdir(),
  file_basename = "Figure2",
  width_in = 6,
  height_in = 4
)

Arguments

data

ssi_run object from run_scenarios().

output_dir

Directory to save the figure (default: temp directory).

file_basename

Base name for the output folder/file (default: "Figure2").

width_in, height_in

Dimensions (inches) for the saved PDF.

Value

Invisibly returns a list with:

  • plot: the ggplot object

  • data: tidy plotting data (one value per iteration)

  • outdir: output directory used

Data source

  • Input is an ssi_run from run_scenarios().

  • Required: ssi_run$parameters must include nyi, nyh, ny, goalfreq, firstrev, review_years. The function validates these and errors if missing.

  • Uses data$results$S_msy: a nested list keyed by scenario (e.g., "scen_<num>"), where each element is a list of numeric vectors (one value per review year) for each iteration.

Review year selection

Review years follow the simulation setup: seq(nyi + firstrev, ny, by = goalfreq). The figure uses the first review at or after calendar year nyi + nyh (i.e., the first post-historical review). Internally this is resolved via .get_review_years() and .get_review_index_post_history().

Scenario filtering & labeling

  • Scenario labels and factor orders are standardized via .standardize_scenario_labels().

  • Keep only factorMSY == "MSY".

  • Exclude trends == "ASL trends continued".

  • Facet by selectivity with scales = "free_y".

Statistics (across iterations)

For each (trends × selectivity × mgmt) cell, compute the median and the central 50% (\(0.25, 0.75\)) and 80% (\(0.10, 0.90\)) intervals of the per-iteration \(S_{MSY}\) values at the selected review.

Plot design

  • x: trends (in order); y: \(S_{MSY}\) (native units; no scaling).

  • color: mgmt with palette c("darkgray","deepskyblue3","orange").

  • Two stat_summary() layers: 80% band (thin) and 50% band (thicker), both centered on the median.

  • y label: \(S_{MSY}\) rendered via expression(""*S[MSY]*"").

Files written

  • file.path(output_dir, "Figure2", "Figure2.pdf")

  • file.path(output_dir, "Figure2", "Figure2.csv")

References

Ohlberger, J., Schindler, D. E., & Staton, B. A. (2025). Accounting for salmon body size declines in fishery management can reduce conservation risks. Fish and Fisheries, 26, 113–130. https://doi.org/10.1111/faf.12869
